label: Letter from Sidney Jennings Legendre, October 21, 1942
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, praising her work ethic, explaining the difficulties when trying to get a phone call in Hawaii, and rejoicing over the beauty of Hawaii. Sidney continues in his letter to express his wishes to see his brother, Armant, stationed in Hawaii soon, informing her that he is not being transferred, and describing his trip to the osteopaths for his back.

metadata.value:
18
October 21, 1942 
Dear Gertie,
I have your letter of the thirteenth and quite agree
with you that the plantation should be rented. Even though you
may not receive five hundred a month for it, I believe it would
be better to take two hundred and have the house occupied than
to let it sit. The advantage of it being occupied is more than
simply having it heated and taken care of during the winter months.
Tennants will prevent any vandalism, and this is what I am afraid
of during this winter when the workers on the project next door
discover we will not be there.
You really sound as if you are the hardest worker
in the world. I would collapse if I worked every night until
eight as you do. Certainly habit is a curious thing. It controls
our ability and endurance, and ten hours a day in time probably
appears to be normal, though at first it seems as if we can
hardly live through lt. Your job must be interesting, and I
think the enlarging of your office and the taking on of additional
secretaries is proof of your ability. Really, I am so proud of
you, and so happy at the thought that on my return I will be able
to lie in a hammock with my jug of corn liker while you run
everything, that my disposition has changed completely.
Even though you did not get the fat spaniel that
liked to eat I am certain that the other is very sweet, and will
probably become very fat by the time Rose and Lucy are through with
him. Please give him a big hug for ms, and be sure to pull
his ears and tell him I hope to come home some day and give him
[End Page 1]
lots of little susages at breakfast time.
You have no doubt received my letter telling you about 
the telephone conversation. I never left the hotel except to
go out on the beach Sunday. The trouble was that they never
called me. I have never spent a night away from the hotel except
when I go to the Navy Yard when we work late at the office, so it
is ridiculous for the operator to say that I am not there.
However the phone situation is a little balled up and they really
have a very hard time running people down when they have to talk
through hotel operators who have some difficult in speaking
English themselves.
There is not the slightest doubt in mymind, but that
I have the best of theplaces we are stationed in. Each day I
realize more and more how really lovely it is here. There is
no change. You can count on the same temperature every morning,
the same brillant sunshine and the evening I know will bring a
wonderful swim, dinner, moonlight, palm trees and my radio.
It is heaven and would be absolutley perfect if you were only here.
I cannot think of working in a city any more than you. But the
combination of work and this setting is a very happy one.
The work prevents boredom, makes you appreciate your days off,
while at the same time every evening is a day off in itself as
there is paddl[e] tennis andswimming,so that you forget all about
the office and sitting in a chair and life becomes a balanced
procession of work and play, and a very agreeable one. Don't let
anyone tell you the boys in Hawaii are suffering, because it
would be impossible unless they force themselves to trump u[p]
[End Page 2]
little grieviences.
I hope to see Armant but have not heard from him for
over a month. You wrote me he had left some time ago, but that
has been the last news I have had as to his whereabouts. It is
possible he may pass by without my seeing him at all as it may
happen that he will not have the opportunity to look me up.
I am not transferring to air intelligence nor do I have
anything specific to do with air duty. However one of the most
important functions is air work and as a result a great part of
this passes over my desk. You need not worry about my volunteering
for carrier work, nor will I go up in a plane, God Willing. The
answer to all your questions is NO. However men with designations
of engineers, supply officers etc. besides myown branch are moved
off very suddenly,as something else, and this of course may
happen to anyone. However I advise youto rely on Moon Face the
Great Chief, he will not be caught napping, he knows all, sees all
and has the answers ready before the questions are asked.
Life and time magazine have not arrived, it makes me
furious because I see other copies arriving forthe men every day.
A bottle of absorbine Jr did come yesterday and sent me into
roaors of laughter. You can buy it in every drugstore here.
However I do want to thank you for the trouble and thought you went
to an sending it to me and thank you very much.
I went to the oesteopath yesterday and had a wonderful
time. The oesteopath turned out to be two women, sisters. They
were tiny and would both swing on one of my arms or legs together.
I do not believe they weighed more than one hundred pounds
together and I could not feel them. Finally one said to the
other "go and get a stool for me to stand on and work on his back."
[End Page 3]
They trled this fora while and then decided that it would be
easier if they worked on me on the floor. We were all laughing so
much at the end that the fun of it cured me far more than the treat-
ment.
Have to stop now and finish up some reports. With all
my love,
Sidney J. Legendre
[End Page 4]
